items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been updated because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is still likely. Water levels are currently stable, but are expected to rise again this evening as high tidal water moves up the rivers from Great Yarmouth. This is due to a natural tide locking effect which is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide of the Broads river system. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed.  We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas.  Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Tuesday 2nd February.

items.description: North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton
items.message: The flood alert for the North Sea coast at Skipton, Hornsea and Mappleton has been issued for this afternoon’s tide, Tuesday 1st February 2022, from 4:00pm until 6:30pm. Strong winds are likely to produce overtopping waves and spray along the coast. The particular area at risk is North Hornsea promenade. Please be careful along beaches, coastal and estuary footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous. We will continue to monitor the forecast and levels closely. This message will be updated before 9:00pm tonight, 1st February 2022 or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: The flood alert for the North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea has been re-issued for this afternoon’s tide, Tuesday 1st February 2022. The alert is in force from 4:30pm until 8:00pm. Strong winds and surge are likely to produce overtopping waves and spray along the coast. The particular areas at risk are around Kilnsea Caravan Park; coastal areas near Southfields Farm, and Spurn Road. Please be careful along beaches, coastal and estuary footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous. Unsettled conditions are expected to continue over the next 24 hours and this alert may remain in force. We will continue to monitor the forecast closely. This message will be updated by 9:00pm tonight, 1st February 2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: The flood alert for the Humber Estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall has been re-issued for this afternoon’s tide, Tuesday 1st February 2022. The alert is in force from 6:30pm until 8:30pm. The particular area of concern is Kilnsea village. Overtopping waves and spray are expected with flooding to roads and farmland possible between these times.  Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads in the Kilnsea area.  Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast.  Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.  This message will be updated before 9:00pm tonight, 1st February 2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hunstanton coast in Norfolk
North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including tidal River Esk
items.message: This flood alert has been issued as overtopping waves and spray are expected as a result of strong winds between 3:30pm and 4:30pm this afternoon, Tuesday 1st February 2022, particularly around Newquay Road, Whitby. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths, promenades and roads and exercise caution in exposed coastal locations. This message will be updated before 9:00pm on 1st February 2022, or as the situation changes.

This is due to a natural tide locking effect which is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide of the Broads river system. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed.  We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay.  Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Tuesday 2nd February.

items.description: Tweed estuary
items.message:
Large and powerful waves are expected as a result of spring tides coupled with a small surge along Tweed Estuary.  Tides will be at their highest at Berwick between the bridges from 14:00 to 16:30, today, 01/02/22. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however adverse conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide which is at 15:30.  Areas most at risk are seaside footpaths and low lying land and roads.   
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads. Stay away from large waves and sea spray as they can be dangerous. 
This message will be updated by 19:00 on 01/02/22, or as the situation changes.

Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: Coast from Ramsgate to Kingsdown
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: This flood alert has been issued as a result of the high tide expected to affect coastal and tidal locations tonight, 01/02/2022. Tides will be at their highest between 11:15pm and 11:45pm tonight, 01/02/2022 with the peak expected at 11:30pm. Flooding will affect lower lying locations nearest the coast throughout this area, between Ramsgate and Kingsdown. The unsettled weather is likely to continue over the coming days so some further periods of flooding are possible this week, we will issue further messages if required. Please be careful in areas around the coast during this period of concern, and avoid contact with flood waters present. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services, our partners and actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. For those that use it, the Total Water Level will be 3.63 mAOD at Dover at 11:30pm tonight, 01/02/2022. This message will be updated tomorrow morning 02/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Somerset coast at Porlock Weir
items.message: Conditions are forecast to ease for the high tide on Monday evening. This flood alert remains in force however for Tuesday morning’s high tide, when a combination of spring tides and strong winds may result in waves and sea spray overtopping sea defences. The forecast high water is at 06:45 on 01/02/2022 with a level of 6.10 mAOD and a Force 6 Westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkley, mAOD is height above average sea level. For more detail please refer to local tide tables. Flooding to coastal areas and vulnerable properties is possible on Tuesday morning, and conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide. We forecast that flooding is possible for the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads. This message will be updated by 14:00 on Tuesday 01/02/2022 or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Hornsea

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, Stream Dike, Foss Beck

items.message: This flood warning has been issued as waves and spray combined with strong winds are forecast to cause overtopping along coastal frontages in Hornsea, particularly around North Promenade, between 4:00pm and 6:30pm on Tuesday 1st February 2022. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary. Please stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as the expected large waves and sea spray will be dangerous. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Consider activating any property flood protection products if you have them. This message will be updated before 9:00pm tonight, 1st February 2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Northumberland coast
items.message:
Large and powerful waves are expected as a result of spring tides coupled with a small surge along Northumberland Coast.  Tides will be at their highest at Beadnell Harbour Road North between 13:45 and 17:30, and at Newbiggin Bay North Promenade between 14:30 and 17:30, today, 01/02/22. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however adverse conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide which is at 15:30.  Areas most at risk are seaside footpaths and low lying land and roads.   
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads. Stay away from large waves and sea spray as they can be dangerous. 
This message will be updated by 19:00 on 01/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Riverside properties along the tidal River Yare including Cantley, Brundall and Reedham
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds which trigger a flood warning. A flood alert remains in place for the wider area.  There is currently low flood risk from high tides for the rest of this morning and into the afternoon. However, it is likely that tides will again be high this evening, Tuesday 1st February, and bring high water levels in the Broads. We will continue to monitor levels closely and issue any messages as necessary.   Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: Isolated low lying properties along the tidal River Waveney
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds which trigger a flood warning. A flood alert remains in place for the wider area. There is currently low flood risk from high tides for the rest of this morning and into the afternoon. However, it is likely that tides will again be high this evening, Tuesday 1st February, and bring high water levels in the Broads.  There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away, especially near the damaged railway embankment along the New Cut at Thorpe and Haddiscoe Fleet north-west of the A143. We will continue to monitor levels closely and issue any messages as necessary.  Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.
